field_reports.description:
In the early morning of August 8, 2025, following a heavy torrential rain, a landslide occurred in the district of Foumban, department of Noun,  simultaneously in the villages of said Mapouoche par Njintout, Njilom, Machinka, Koudounka). It should be noted that this same locality had already been subject to a landslide in 2018. The district and departmental committees of the Red Cross of the Noun department immediately went down to the field to assess the situation. The toll to date is nearly 3600 people directly affected, i.e. 500 households.  There is no loss of human life but significant material damage is to be deplored, namely: 165 households without shelter because their houses have been completely destroyed as well as household items, damaged community infrastructure (roads, bridges, places of worship, graves, easements, commercial buildings; toilets).

The rainy season is in full swing and the national weather forecast announces an increase in rainfall that could lead to a series of floods in several parts of the country, including the West region. There is an urgent need for action to save lives.

results.summary:
Cameroon faces recurrent cholera outbreaks, exacerbated by seasonal floods, inadequate WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) infrastructure, and rapid urbanization. Historical outbreaks, such as the 2021–2022 epidemic, which recorded 6,652 suspected cases and 132 deaths, highlight
vulnerabilities in high-risk regions like Littoral, Southwest, and Center. Climate change and population displacement further amplify the risks, making early intervention crucial. The Early Action Protocol (EAP) was developed collaboratively through multi-stakeholder workshops in 2024, involving the Cameroon Red Cross (CRC), the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Water and Environment, WHO, UNICEF, MSF, and other key partners. A comprehensive risk analysis was conducted to prioritize districts based on historical cholera incidence, vulnerability indices, and climatic factors, ensuring a targeted and effective response. The protocol aims to support 2,500 households—approximately 13,500 people—living in 56 high-risk districts identified as cholera “hotspots.” These areas are characterized by poor access to WASH services, overcrowding, and high exposure to floods, making them particularly susceptible to outbreaks.
results.name: CMR: Cholera EAP

field_reports.description:
Heavy torrential rains fell in the MayoDanay department in the Far North region of Cameroon and more precisely in the Districts of Kai-kai and Vélé on August 15, 16 and 17, 2024. The 12  villages affected in the district of Vélé are Waidoua, Meringué, Voundaram, Wakka, Gabaraye; and in the vicinity of Kai-kai the villages of Ndoukroye, Manga, Tarsia, Djafga, Begué Palam, Dougoui, Djoulékou, Doreissou. 

As soon as the iondations occurred, the Vele and Kai-kai district committees under the supervision of the Mayo Danay departmental committee immediately went down to the field to assess the situation. Significant damage emerged, namely:

  • fields drowned in water. (approx. 22 hectares)
  •  1320 houses completely destroyed and 803 partially destroyed
  • loss of household essentials (bedding, clothing)
  • Losses of poultry and small ruminants

 A total  of 1062 affected households (5297 people) including 221 households (1105 people) in an emergency situation. The situation is likely to worsen in view of the rains that continue to fall. Most of the affected households have found refuge in host families and in makeshift sites, exposing themselves to bad weather and other diseases. The widespread insalubrity in the flooded villages following the overflow of latrines and some water points exposes them to waterborne diseases such as cholera.

The access roads to these boroughs are currently impassable, isolating these communities. 

In view of the fairly large number of people with special needs,

  • 48 breastfeeding women
  • 898 children under 5 years of age
  • 84 pregnant women
  • 20 people living with a disability
  • Action is urgently needed
  •  
  • Faced with this situation and with the help of empty bags stored by the FIU, the departmental committee of the Red Cross of MayoDanay with the support of the CRF have as part of the disaster risk reduction activities initiated the construction of crossing structures, construction of water retention bunds to avoid the worst.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Inondation - 08-2024 - inondation Logone et Chari
field_reports.description:
La région de l’extrême-Nord Cameroun en général, et le département du Logone et Chari en particulier a enregistré cette année une pluviométrie sans précédents. La récurrence des pluies depuis le mois de juillet à Août 2024, associée à une succession de fortes pluies diluviennes (avec une durée moyenne d’environ 7 heures par averse, du 11/08/2024 au 19/08/2024), ont plongé le département de Logone et Chari, dans une série d’inondations pluviales. Les Arrondissements les plus touchés sont   Blangoua, Makary et Zina avec plus d’une dizaine de villages complètement inondés. De même, quelques localités dans les arrondissements de Logone birni, Kousseri et goulfey sont touchées.

Ces inondations viennent trouver des communautés vulnérables du fait du changement climatique, des poches de sècheresse, des invasions d’acridiens, des invasions d’oiseaux granivores, des invasions des pachydermes et du contexte sécuritaire très volatile depuis 2014. Tous ces facteurs affectent considérablement les capacités de résilience et les moyens de subsistances de ces communautés.

Dès la survenue des inondations, des évaluations de la situation ont été faites du 12 au 20/08/2024 par les comités d’arrondissement de Blangoua, de Makary et de Zina sous la supervision du Comité départemental du Logone et Chari. Ces évaluations font état d’un bilan provisoire de 13140 ménages directement affectés et en situation d'urgence dans les 03 arrondissement pour 91 980 personnes (soit 4095 ménages à Blangoua, 7309 ménages à Makary et 1736 ménages à ZINA) ainsi que d’importants dégâts humains matériels :

-          03 pertes en vie humaine, soit 01 personne dans la localité de Maltam à Makary, et 02 personnes respectivement dans les villages de Bangalia et de Ndoulo dans l’arrondissement de Zina ;

-          4543 cases détruites (soit 2667 cases à makary, 1031 cases à Blangoua et 845 cases à Zina) ;

-           2985 Ha de culture engloutis par les eaux (soit 1494 Ha à Makary, 316 Ha à Blangoua et 1175 Ha à Zina) ;

-           Plus de 601 petits ruminants et volailles y compris perdus (soit 236 animaux à makary, 84 animaux à Blangoua et 281 animaux à Zina) ;

-           Plusieurs les points d’eau et latrines inondés ;

-          La destruction des biens matériels et des documents civils.

.- 03 cas de décès dans la commune du Logone Birni (01 femme allaitante, 01 nourrisson, un enfant de 04 ans).

Les sinistrés vivent actuellement à la belle étoile et l’on compte un grand nombre de personnes à besoins spécifiques (les enfants, les femmes enceinte, les femmes allaitantes et les personnes âgées) à la merci des intempéries et des risques sanitaires éventuelles. Quelques ménages sinistrés se sont abrités dans les infrastructures des fortunes (CMPJ, CEEAC, les écoles, DAADER, lieu de stationnement de véhicules de voyage) et d’autres accueillis dans les communautés hôtes.

Les prévisions météorologiques prévoient de fortes pluies jusqu'au mois de septembre 2024, ce qui aggraverait la situation des localités déjà touchées et une extension probable vers les autres localités encore épargnées.  De plus les prévisions météorologiques nationales, prévoient des crues du fleuve Logone durant la troisième décade du mois d’août 2024 (du 21 au 31), des crues du fleuves Logone sont prévues.

Les risques  sont divers à savoir: 

  •      La menace d’épidémie de paludisme avec la prolifération des moustiques en cette période ;
  •  La menace d’une possibilité risque d’épidémie de choléra, vu l’insalubrité et l’inondation des latrines occasionnées ;
  •   Les vols des effets des sinistrés pouvant engendrer des conflits ;
  •  Le retard d’une assistance adéquate pourrait favoriser la dégradation des conditions de vie des personnes sinistrées ;
  • La probabilité élevée de survenue d’inondation fluviale  dû au débordement des fleuves Logone et EL-BEID qui pourrait aggraver et accentuer la situation à l’échelle du département.

results.summary:
The Far North region of Cameroon in general, and the department of Logone and Chari in particular, recorded unprecedented rainfall this year. The recurrence of rains since July to August 2024, combined with a succession of heavy torrential rains (with an average duration of about 7 hours per shower, from 11/08/2024 to 19/08/2024), have plunged the department of Logone and Chari into a series of rainfall floods. The most affected districts are   Blangoua, Makary and Zina with more than a dozen villages completely flooded. Similarly, some localities in the districts of Logone birni, Kousseri and goulfey are affected.

These floods are finding vulnerable communities due to climate change, pockets of drought, locust invasions, seed-eating bird invasions, pachyderm invasions and the very volatile security context since 2014. All of these factors significantly affect the resilience and livelihoods of these communities.

As soon as the floods occurred, assessments of the situation were made from 12 to 20/08/2024 by the district committees of Blangoua, Makary and Zina under the supervision of the Logone and Chari Departmental Committee. These assessments report a provisional assessment of 13140 households directly affected and in an emergency situation in the 03 arrondissements for 91,980 people (i.e. 4095 households in Blangoua, 7309 households in Makary and 1736 households in ZINA) as well as significant human material damage:

-          03 loss of human life, i.e. 01 person in the locality of Maltam in Makary, and 02 people respectively in the villages of Bangalia and Ndoulo in the district of Zina;

-          4543 huts destroyed (i.e. 2667 huts in Makary, 1031 huts in Blangoua and 845 huts in Zina);

-           2985 ha of crops swallowed up by the waters (i.e. 1494 ha in Makary, 316 ha in Blangoua and 1175 ha in Zina);

-           More than 601 small ruminants and poultry including lost (i.e. 236 animals in Makary, 84 animals in Blangoua and 281 animals in Zina);

-           Several flooded water points and latrines;

-          The destruction of material property and civil documents.

- 03 cases of death in the commune of Logone Birni (01 breastfeeding woman, 01 infant, a child of 04 years old).

The victims are currently living under the stars and there are a large number of people with special needs (children, pregnant women, breastfeeding women and the elderly) at the mercy of bad weather and possible health risks. Some affected households have taken shelter in the infrastructure of the fortunes (CMPJ, ECCAS, schools, DAADER, place where travel vehicles are parked) and others have been accommodated in the host communities.

Weather forecasts predict heavy rains until September 2024, which would worsen the situation of the localities already affected and a probable extension to the other localities still spared.  In addition, the national weather forecasts predict flooding of the Logone River during the third dekad of August 2024 (from 21 to 31), flooding of the Logone River is forecast.

The risks are diverse, namely:

  •      The threat of a malaria epidemic with the proliferation of mosquitoes during this period;
  •  The threat of a possibility of a cholera epidemic is a risk, given the unsanitary conditions and the flooding of the latrines caused;
  •   The theft of the effects of the victims can lead to conflicts;
  •  The delay in adequate assistance could contribute to the deterioration of the living conditions of the people affected;
  • The high probability of river flooding due to the overflow of the Logone and EL-BEID rivers, which could aggravate and accentuate the situation at the departmental level.

field_reports.description:
Heavy torrential  rains fell in the Mayo-Danay department,
Far North Region of Cameroon and more precisely in the District of Yagoua from August 04 , 2024, for nearly 8 hours of non-stop time. These rains continued on August 05 and 06, 2024, causing flooding in several districts of the city of Yagoua. The most affected neighbourhoods are Djibetsou (with 78 households affected), Guidangmoutou (41 households), Danayré (64 households) and Hléké (34 households). 
The provisional assessment shows that 221 households were directly affected, i.e. nearly 1105 people, as well as several fairly significant damages such as the partial or total destruction of houses;   loss of certain material goods, including sleeping materials and clothing; the loss of small rumunants and fowls. 
 No loss of life was reported, but the number of victims continues to rise in view of the continuing rains and the fact that most of  the houses are made of dirt. 
 The victims had to leave their homes to find refuge in the shelters of host families. 

The vulnerability of those affected and their numbers is likely to increase in the coming days and weeks if nothing is done. The affected people include a large number of people with special needs, i.e. nearly 762 people: 114 pregnant women; 119 lactating women; 498 children under 5 years of age; 31 elderly people and 7 people living with a disability. These people are exposed to water-related diseases and cholera, as the waters have caused some toilets to overflow. Food pressure at the level of host families is likely to set in.

field_reports.description:
Heavy torrential rains fell in the Diamaré Department, Far North Region of Cameroon on July 28, 2024, causing flooding in several neighborhoods, the most affected of which is the Palar 2 district, particularly the Massinika areas; palar galion and Zaika with nearly 951 people directly affected for 122 households. These rains persisted on July 29 and 30, which generated an increase in the water level, and since this rainfall the quarter has been completely flooded.

    These torrential rains caused  quite significant damage such as destroyed houses, the destruction of material property, the loss of small ruminants and poultry, wells were swallowed up by the water and clogged pipeways. Some plots are no longer habitable because of the stagnant water that destroys the foundations of the houses made of earth. No loss of human life was recorded. However, houses are still threatened under the weight of humidity and flowing, stagnant water. Many households can no longer cook or have dignified sleeping spaces due to a lack of dry space. 

Some of the victims  have left the neighbourhood to find refuge with their family members, others under the stars in less humid places, others currently under the stars in less  humid places and there are some who, despite the unsanitary conditions, continue to occupy their homes. For the moment, two temporary resettlement sites have been identified, namely  the CES of Palar and the villa of the district chief. Some toilet structures have been destroyed, forcing the population to create makeshift toilets.  It should be noted that there are a large number of people with special needs, 11 pregnant women; 27 lactating women; 125 children under 5 years old, 34 elderly people and 04 people living with disabilities.  The rainy season is in full swing and the situation could get worse if nothing is done

The Departmental Committee in collaboration with the District Committee and the head of the Palar block mobilized first aid volunteers to help with the evacuation as well as provide first aid.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Displacement - 07-2024 - Movement of populations vele_mayo danay
field_reports.description:
L’Arrondissement de Vélé, dans le département du Mayo-Danay a reçu en date du 03 juillet
2024, 152 ménages soit 881 personnes à la suite d'affrontements entre deux peuples frères
au Tchad voisin.  Ces familles ont traversé la frontière pour fuir la violence et ont provisoirement trouvé refuge dans les locaux des écoles primaires Groupe1 et 2 de Vélé , de Guémé, de Dobo et d’autres chez leurs connaissances et familles hôtes. Les localités en conflit sont celles de Magaye, Mbouktang, Moulsou contre Fara, Tchodira,Hidig et Soumai. Les victimes qui ont traversé la frontière vers le Cameroun, proviennent principalement des localités de Magaye et Mbouktang.

Selon les informations concordantes collectées au sein de cette communauté déplacée, cette bagarre rangée part de ce que deux  jeunes initiés qui poursuivaient un chien jusqu’à son domicile battu le chien ainsi que son propriétaire. Les voisins sont intervenus et l'échange s’est transformé en bagarre rangée.
Le bilan de la première bagarrefait état d'un (01) mort et plus de 20 blessés.
Trois (03) jours après le décès, à la suite d'un rite de purification au cours duquel , la famille de la victime aurait  déposé dans le camp adverse des cendres, un second affrontement plus violent que le précédent aurait éclaté faisant  un (01) mort et de nombreux blessés graves actuellement sous soins intensifs dans certaines formations sanitaires du Tchad et celles du Cameroun. C'est à la suite de ce second affrontements que certaines familles ont fui vers le Cameroun. Il convient de préciser que ces localités ne sont pas à leur première expérience de bagarres rangées, mais de moindre ampleur, qui  ont souvent conduit à des déplacements internes à l'intérieur du Tchad.  L'ampleur de cette bagarre a contraint les sinistrés cette fois-ci à effectuer un mouvement transfrontalier. Ce déplacement vers le Cameroun
s’explique du fait de la proximité de leur village d’origine d'avec certaines localités du Mayo Danay, ainsi que de la similarité des considérations ethniques et sociales entre les localités.

Les arrivées sur le territoire camerounais se font de manière progressive car semble t-il les agressions continuent. Les premiers sites d'accueil au niveau de l'arrondissement de Vele étant pleins, les nouveaux arrivants se sont installés à l’école koko et à Balgam dans l’arrondissement de Kai-kai, dans des familles d'accueil et d'autres sont à la belle étoile exposés aux intempéries de toute nature.

Informé de la situation, le Comité départemental de la Croix-Rouge du Mayo-Danay représenté par son Président ainsi que le Disaster Manager et de 10 volontaires, a effectué une descente une évaluation rapide de la situation. Cette évaluation fait état de la présence de près de 148 ménages pour 838  personnes, d'un nombre important de personnes à besoins spécifiques au sein de ces familles déplacées:131 femmes enceintes; 164 femmes allaitantes; 318 enfants de moins de 5 ans et 39 personnes âgées. Ces chiffres continuent de croître. Les familles déplacées déclarent également la perte  de biens matériels, de leurs maisons, des petits/gros ruminants, des volailles, des habits, ustensiles de cuisine, des couvertures, des
nattes, jerrycans et des vivres etc. Elles se retrouvent ainsi dans un état de précarité extrême. Et si rien n'est fait la situation pourrait s'empirer exposant du même coup les communautés d'accueil.

Le Sous-Préfet de l'arrondissement de Vele et son état major ainsi que le Maire de la commune de Vele ont effectué une visite sur les différents sites pour s'enquerrir de la situation. Ils ont appelé à la solidarité communautaire et à celle des élites locales. Le chef de district de santé a fait don d'un ballot de moustiquaires aux plus vulnérables.

A ce jour aucune organisation humanitaire n'est descendue sur le terrain.

results.summary:
The Arrondissement of Vélé, in the department of Mayo-Danay, received on July 03
2024, 148 households or 838 people following clashes between two brotherly peoples
in neighbouring Chad.  These families crossed the border to flee the violence and temporarily found refuge in the premises of the Group 1 and 2 primary schools in Vélé, Guémé, Dobo and others with their acquaintances and host families. The localities in conflict are those of Magaye, Mbouktang, Moulsou against Fara, Tchodira, Hidig and Soumai. The victims who crossed the border into Cameroon are mainly from the localities of Magaye and Mbouktang.

According to the concordant information collected within this displaced community, this pitched fight starts from the fact that two  young initiates who were chasing a dog to its home beat the dog as well as its owner. The neighbors intervened and the exchange turned into a pitched fight.
The toll of the first fight is one (01) dead and more than 20 injured.
Three (03) days after the death, following a purification rite during which the victim's family would have  deposited ashes in the opposing camp, a second clash more violent than the previous one would have broken out causing  one (01) death and many serious injuries currently under intensive care in some health facilities Chad and Cameroon. It was following this second clash that some families fled to Cameroon. It should be noted that these localities are not at their first experience of pitched fights, but on a smaller scale, which  have often led to internal displacement within Chad.  The scale of this fight forced the victims this time to make a cross-border movement. This trip to Cameroon
This is due to the proximity of their village of origin to certain localities in Mayo Danay, as well as the similarity of ethnic and social considerations between the localities.

Arrivals on Cameroonian territory are taking place gradually because it seems that aggressions continue. The first reception sites in the Vele district are full, so the new arrivals have settled in koko school and Balgam in Kai-kai district, with host families and others are under the stars exposed to bad weather of all kinds.

Informed of the situation, the Mayo-Danay Departmental Committee of the Red Cross represented by its President as well as the Disaster Manager and 10 volunteers, carried out a rapid assessment of the situation. This assessment reports the presence of nearly 148 households for 838  people, a large number of people with special needs within these displaced families: 131 pregnant women; 164 nursing women; 318 children under 5 years old and 39 elderly people. These numbers continue to grow. Displaced families also report the loss  of material goods, their homes, small/large ruminants, poultry, clothes, kitchen utensils, blankets, food, food,
mats, jerry cans and provisions, etc. They thus find themselves in a state of extreme precariousness. And if nothing is done, the situation could get worse, exposing the host communities at the same time.

The Sub-Prefect of the district of Vele and his staff as well as the Mayor of the municipality of Vele visited the various sites to inquire about the situation. They called for community solidarity and that of local elites. The district health chief donated a bundle of mosquito nets to the most vulnerable.

To date, no humanitarian organization has been on the ground.

field_reports.summary: RMC: Fire - 05-2024 - fire camps IDP's MORA
field_reports.description:
On April 26, 2024, following a fire of accidental origin, 03 camps for internally displaced persons set up in the locality of Doulo, district of Mora, were totally destroyed. These are the Talla Moalloum, Goumouldi and Karassi-Limani camps. With the help of the dry season, and the shelters being built of temporary materials, the fire quickly spread beyond the area occupied by these communities, thus nearly 4 hectares were burned.

These affected IDPs are of Kanouri, Shoa and Mandara ethnic affiliation. They are believed to have moved as a result of the internal border conflict in the Far North Region, and have been living in Doulo for more than a decade.

The assessment report of the Departmental Committee of Mayo Sava, which went down to the field as soon as the fire was reported, mentions several material damages, including the loss of livestock; food;   motorcycles and bicycles; cash and essential household items.  

 According to the same report, these communities are currently living in the open without assistance. The affected population is made up of a fairly large number of people with special needs.

  • 64 lactating women
  • 85 pregnant women
  • 50 seniors

results.summary:
On April 26, 2024, following a fire of accidental origin, 03 camps for internally displaced persons set up in the locality of Doulo, district of Mora, were totally destroyed. These are the Talla Moalloum, Goumouldi and Karassi-Limani camps. With the help of the dry season, and the shelters being built of temporary materials, the fire quickly spread beyond the area occupied by these communities, thus nearly 4 hectares were burned.

These affected IDPs are of Kanouri, Shoa and Mandara ethnic affiliation. They are believed to have moved as a result of the internal border conflict in the Far North Region, and have been living in Doulo for more than a decade.

The assessment report of the Departmental Committee of Mayo Sava, which went down to the field as soon as the fire was reported, mentions several material damages, including the loss of livestock; food;   motorcycles and bicycles; cash and essential household items.

field_reports.description:
On the night of March 08, 2024, heavy rain accompanied by strong winds fell in the city of Yaoundé, Mfoundi Department . Several districts of the department  are concerned, the most affected of which are the districts of Yaoundé 3 and Yaoundé 6.

As a result of this heavy rain, several houses were destroyed as well as household equipment and furniture.  The force of the storm led to the destruction of electrical installations, which plunged the affected areas into darkness. 

According to the information gathered, several neighbourhoods have been affected, including NGOA-EKELLE (University Residential Area);  EFOULAN; MVOGT BETSI; MELEN;OBILI and ETOUG EBE. 

Faced with this situation, the Departmental Committee of MFOUNDI conducted on March 9, an assessment of the situation in the most affected neighborhoods of OBILI, more precisely in front of the Presidential Guard (MELEN BLOCK 8), and ETOUG EBE behind the high school. The provisional toll is: 05 injured, including a pregnant woman;  01 deceased;  several houses partially destroyed due to torn roofs and cracked walls;school infrastructure partially destroyed;  damaged home  equipment; destroyed school supplies; official documents (birth certificates, National Identity Cards, diplomas, etc.) destroyed;  Damaged electronic devices (computers)  

Some residents are trying to redo temporary roofs to shelter from the next rains.

During this assessment visit, about a hundred affected families were visited and several material damages, cases of injury and one death were reported. It should be noted that these neighbourhoods have experienced an explosion in population since the crisis-related population movements in the North-West and South-West regions. These neighborhoods are home to thousands of internally displaced persons (IDPs). Displaced populations live in precarious conditions and are mostly unemployed.The situation in which they find themselves after this rain only exacerbates their already worrying situation, these populations need urgent assistance. 

The rainy season is at the beginning of its season and these populations remain exposed to flooding just as much as the entire city of Yaoundé.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Déplacement de population - 02-2024 - Mouvement des populations tchadiennes dans le Logone Birni
field_reports.description:
Dans la journée du 21 février 2024 aux environs de 15heures, quatre chefs traditionnels du village GAMAL (localité tchadienne) se sont réfugiés dans la dans la localité de GALA au Cameroun suivis de leur communauté. Ce déplacement subite serait parti de différends fonciers avec un Général de l'armée. Les populations se sentant en insécurité se sont déplacées vers le Cameroun dans la localité de Gala (village voisin situé de l'autre du fleuve Logone), Arrondissement du Logone Birni. A ce jour l'on décompte 225 familles avec près de 700 personnes à besoins spécifiques (femmes enceintes et allaitantes, personnes de troisième âge, enfants orphelins, des blessés; des handicapés).

 Ces familles vivent dans des hutes, des hangars construits avec des materiaux de fortune, défequant à l'air libre. Installées au bord du fleuve, ces communautés utilisent l'eau du fleuve en l'état pour toute utilisation et consommation, ce qui les expose fortement au risque  de maladies hydriques , notamment le choléra.  Ces communautés ont besoin d'une aide d'urgence.

results.summary:
On February 21, 2024 at around 3 p.m., four traditional chiefs from the village of GAMAL (Chadian locality) took refuge in the locality of GALA in Cameroon followed by their community. This sudden displacement is said to have started from land disputes with an army general. The populations feeling insecure have moved to Cameroon in the locality of Gala (a neighboring village located on the other side of the Logone River), in the Logone Birni District. To date, there are 225 families with nearly 700 people with special needs (pregnant and breastfeeding women, the elderly, orphaned children, the injured, the disabled).

 These families live in huts, sheds built with makeshift materials, defecating in the open. Settled on the banks of the river, these communities use the water of the river as it is for all use and consumption, which exposes them to the high risk  of waterborne diseases, including cholera.  These communities need urgent assistance.
results.name: CMR: Population displacement - 02-2024 - Movement of Chadian populations in Logone Birni

field_reports.description:
On the morning of Thursday, February 08, 2024, the internally displaced persons of the IDP camps of Manawatchi, Ndaba, Bamé-mélleri, Kidjimatari and Kordo, installed in the city center of Kolofata on the outskirts of Mayo, were surprised by a fire. Of accidental origin according to the testimonies received, the fire spread at an exponential speed, setting fire to several households in the above-mentioned IDP camps, and whose structures are essentially made of local and temporary materials (millet stalks, tree branches, etc.). The fire lasted about 2 hours before being brought under control by the population.

The Kolofata District Committee, supported by the Departmental Committee, immediately went to the field to provide support (evacuation of the victims; participation in the control of the fire) to the population and conducted a rapid assessment which  reported the destruction of material property (houses, sleeping equipment; kitchen utensils, clothes, food reserves), small financial savings were completely destroyed, serious injuries (1 56-year-old woman) and loss of life (7- and 9-year-old children). A total of 189 households, i.e. approximately 1323 people directly affected. This evaluation involved 6 volunteers.

As soon as the situation was triggered, the Sub-Prefect of the District of Kolofata and his staff, as well as all the traditional authorities, went to the field to take stock of the situation. Other humanitarian actors have remained absent in the area since the call was issued following the kidnapping of Première Urgence Internationale (PUI) personnel.

     Dueto the insecurity in the area; The victims remained at the scene. Community solidarity under the leadership of religious and traditional authorities (Lawanes and Blamas) was set up and the victims were able to receive a few makeshift mats, tarpaulins and used loincloths. 

         The Cameroon Red Cross, through the local branch, continues to provide psychological support to the community and to monitor the evolution of the situation.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Other - 12-2023 - Risk of diphtheria epidemic Cameroon
field_reports.description:
The Minister of Public Health, in a letter dated November 07, 2023, instructed the regional public health delegates to strengthen diphtheria surveillance.  This communication from the Minister of Public Health comes following the notification of a suspected case in Yaoundé, Central Region, by the central hospital.
Diphtheria is a serious, infectious and contagious, sometimes fatal, bacterial infection of the upper airways. Signs and symptoms usually appear 2 to 5 days after exposure and range in severity from mild to severe. It is caused by a bacterium Corynebacterium diphtheriae that releases a powerful toxin, which can damage the heart, kidneys and nervous system. It is spread through direct contact or through the air, with respiratory droplets emitted when a person coughs or sneezes. The disease can also be spread through contact with contaminated clothing or objects. 

according to the WHO health emergency report of 12 November 2023 on the diphtheria outbreak, several African countries are currently in an epidemic situation, including Guinea, Niger, Mauritania, South Africa and Nigeria. Nigeria has the highest number of cases with 83.0% of all cases and 73.3% of deaths in epidemiological week 45.
According to the Government, Nigeroa has nearly 7,000 confirmed cases with 471 deaths. To consider the geographical position with Cameroon; the risk of importation of the epidemic is very high both in the border regions (South-West, West, North), and in the interior of the country, especially in the large cities (Yaoundé, Douala, Bafoussam).
 The Centre Region has an estimated population of more than 5 million inhabitants, with the city of Yaoundé alone having nearly 3 million inhabitants, according to the National Institute of Statistics (2015). If the outbreak were to be confirmed and spread, approximately 12 million people would be exposed. 
The overcrowded conditions in several parts of the city are a very important factor that would favour a rapid spread of the disease if it were to reach the population.
It should also be noted that the lack of knowledge of the population about this disease may represent a risk.

field_reports.description:
in the

evening of October 08, 2023 at around 6 p.m. following a very heavy and long rain of more than 2 hours of the time, landslides occurred in the Mankolo district lieut called "Febe village". at the site of the disaster there was a large ravine that shelters one of the sources of the Mfoundi River, and that rainwater over time has eroded. More than forty years ago, an artificial lake was built on this site, and several populations have settled there because of the beauty of the place,  which has become almost a tourist site. Due to the relief of the site, which is very steep, the riverine populations had built a retaining wall on the slope of the lake, leaving a very small runoff passage for the water.

After this very heavy rain, the waters of the lake could not find a way through and broke the protective wall, grazing all the houses in the path. All these houses were buried in the mudslide.

To date, the damage is incalculable as many people remain unaccounted for and excavations continue. According to the figures made public at the moment, 28 deceased people have been found, many people remain missing, more than twenty houses have been  devastated by the violent and sudden mudslide. The population directly affected is estimated at around 300 people. 

Evaluations are underway and the figures may evolve according to the progress of the excavations and researches.

Fields, houses, livestock were destroyed. The most affected villages are Makaroua, Mirbidim, Mala and Pit-Arrey. Since August 12, these Chadian populations have gradually moved to Cameroon   especially in the village of Moula, Maga district, Mayo Danay Department.  The figures of the census carried out by the administrative authorities show 272 households or 1,962 persons. These populations have not taken anything with them and therefore live in very precarious conditions that aggravate their vulnerability. The first assessments made it possible to identify the needs for bedding materials, hygiene equipment, food needs, essential household equipment. L people keep arriving. This figure could change.

field_reports.description:
Heavy rain accompanied by winds fell continuously in the city of Limbe from 18 to 19 July 2023. These rains caused flooding in several areas of the city of LImbé (including Church Street, and Down Beach) and landslides in Mawoh. Many damages could be observed including destruction of residential houses, destruction of shops; destruction of household property, disappearance, and loss of life. 
The rains have continued to fall unexpectedly since July 19 and flooding is spreading to other neighborhoods. Thus, on the night of July 20 to 21, another landslide took place in the UPPER CASSAVA FARMS district  with 02 deaths of a 62-year-old woman and a child under 02 years old. There were also about 05 houses invaded by rainwater. 
Nearly 245 people have left their homes invaded by rainwater to seek refuge with host families. Families who continue to stay in their homes in notoriously unsanitary conditions. thus exposing themselves to diseases.  Stagnant water has formed throughout the city. It should be recalled that the city of Limbe experienced an outbreak of cholera epidemic in January 2023 and therefore remains an active focus. Current conditions could favour a new outbreak that is more violent than the previous one. These communities are therefore very exposed, hence the need to take immediate action to support these communities.
The National Observatory on Climate Change (ONACC) has issued an alert on the risk of flooding and landslides following the abundant rains  announced for the period from 21 to 30 July 2023. The South-West Region including the cities Tiko, Idenau, Mamfe and Limbe could record rainfall around  350 mm. If that were to happen, nearly half of the city would be flooded.

The current great rainy season is expected to extend until August and probably September 2023.    The  situation could intensify, endangering people's lives.

Many damages could be observed including destruction of residential houses, destruction of shops; destruction of household property, disappearance, and loss of life.

The ONCC report  indicates that this decade will be marked by heavy rains accompanied by strong winds, thunderstorms, lightning and hail in many localities in the Regions of the Centre, South, East, Littoral, South-West and West, with a risk of recording flood situations in certain agglomerations of the Littoral region (Douala, Nkongsamba) and South-West (Limbe, Tiko).

According to the weather forecast for the decade from 04 to 14 July, the South-West Region will experience a significant increase in precipitation  throughout the rainy season .
it should be remembered that On March 18, 2023, the city of Buea located in the South-West Region of the country, already knew flooding due to runoff from Mount Cameroon.
As the rainy season is only at the beginning of the rainy season, the situation could intensify, endangering people's lives.

field_reports.description:
Dans la journée du 18 mars 2023, la ville de Buea située dans la Région du Sud-Ouest du pays,  a connu une forte pluie qui a provoqué des inondations du fait des eaux de ruissellement provenant du mont Cameroun . Le quartier le plus touché est Soppo Market. Le ruissellement de ces eaux a causé plusieurs dégâts dont la destruction d'habitations situées au pied du mont, la destruction de marchandises dans les boutiques du marché, des blessés et  des décès.

il convient de relever que naturellement la ville de Buea est située dans une plaine et dont très exposée aux inondations en cas de fortes précipitations régulières. Cette situation a été exacerbée lla crise socio-politique qui perdure dans cette Région du Pays a occasionné un fort exode rural des villages moins sécures vers les centres urbains (Buea, Limbe et Tiko...) Les populations vulnérables ont batit leurs habitations sur les marécages fermant ainsi le passage aux eaux de ruissellement. ce qui est de nature à favoriser les inondations et les maladies.

Le rapport de la salle de veille du continent du  Système Africain Multirisque d'Alerte et d'Action Précoce pour la RRC du 10 Mars classait déjà le Cameroun à une alerte de niveau 2.

Selon l'observatoire Nationale, la décade allant du 11 au 20 Mars sera marquée par par de fortes pluies accompagnées de vents violents avec un risque d'inondations notamment dans certaines agglomérations des Régions du Littoral (Douala et Nkongsamba), de l'Ouest, du Nord-Ouest et du Sud Ouest (Buea, Limbe et Tiko). 

Les pluies vont continuer de tomber car ce n'est que le début de la saison des pluies qui ira jusqu'à la fin du mois d'Avril. Le risque que la situation s'aggrave et progresse vers d'autres quartiers et villages est très élévé.

le Comité Départemental du Fako a effectué une descente sur le terrain hier 18 Mars pour appuyer l'évacuation des personnes habitant les maisons effondrées notamment les habitants de l'Eglise Presbytérienne et certains autres habitants qui ont provisoirement trouvé refuge dans les familles amies. les évaluations continuent pour voir comment venir en aide à la population sinistrée.

results.summary:
On March 18, 2023, the city of Buea, located in the South-West Region of the country,  experienced heavy rain that caused flooding due to runoff water from Mount Cameroon. The most affected area is Soppo Market. The runoff of this water caused several damages including the destruction of houses located at the foot of the mountain, the destruction of goods in the market shops, injuries and  deaths.

it should be noted that naturally the city of Buea is located in a plain and therefore very exposed to flooding in the event of regular heavy rainfall. This situation has been exacerbated by the ongoing socio-political crisis in this region of the country that has caused a strong rural exodus from less secure villages to urban centres (Buea, Limbe and Tiko, etc.). Vulnerable populations have built their homes on the swamps, thus closing the passage to runoff. which is likely to encourage flooding and disease.

The report of the African  Multi-Risk Alert and Early Action System for DRR on 10 March already classified Cameroon at a level 2 alert.

According to the National Observatory, the decade from March 11 to 20 will be marked by heavy rains accompanied by strong winds with a risk of flooding, particularly in some cities of the Littoral (Douala and Nkongsamba), West, North-West and South-West regions (Buea, Limbe and Tiko). 

The rains will continue to fall because it is only the beginning of the rainy season which will last until the end of April. The risk that the situation will worsen and spread to other neighbourhoods and villages is very high.

The Departmental Committee of Fako carried out a raid on the ground yesterday, March 18, to support the evacuation of people living in the collapsed houses, including the inhabitants of the Presbyterian Church and some other inhabitants who have temporarily found refuge with friendly families. Assessments continue to see how to help the affected population.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Epidemic - 2023-02 - Anticipatory action for Marburg
field_reports.description:
Since February 7, 2023, several suspected cases with symptoms of Marburg Hemorrhagic Fever have been declared in Equatorial Guinea in districts of Kie-Ntem province. On February 13, 2023, the first Marburg epidemic was declared by confirmation of a positive sample. Several contact cases are to be traced and Cameroon has recorded suspect cases since 9th February in areas bordering Equatorial Guinea.

Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea share a 189 km long border. On both sides of this border, live the Ntumu
populations, who are part of the Fang group. They are established in the North-West of Gabon, also on the other side of the border in the South of Cameroon and in the East of Equatorial Guinea. They are found in Cameroon in the Ntem valley, in the districts of Kyé-Ossi, Ambam, Olamze and Ma'an. Despite their different historical backgrounds, these populations still share fraternal and cultural ties (funeral rites, traditional ceremonies, etc.), economic (trade) and social ties that punctuate their daily life.

Faced with the high risk of spread of the disease, the local administrative authorities have restricted the movement of populations at the Cameroon - Equatorial Guinea border and activated the incident  management system throughout the region.

field_reports.summary: CMR: Landslide - 2022-11 - Eboulement de terrain quartier Damas à Yaoundé
field_reports.description: Ce 27 Novembre 2022, alors que des populations étaient dans la célébration des funérailles d'un des leurs sur une aire de jeu du quartier Damas dans le 3ème Arrondissement de Yaoundé, un pan abrupte asse important de terres'est détaché et s'est renversé sur la tente qui abritait les invités. Ils se sont ainsi retrouvés pris au piège à la fois de la bâche et de la terre. La population attirée par les cris a commencé à procéder à un sauvetage à qui mieux mieux. Malheureusement, malgré les efforts des riverains, plusieurs personnes n'ont pas pu être sauvées. Alertés les secours (Gendarmeries, Police Croix-Rouge Camerounaise et le Corps National des Sapeurs Pompiers) se sont rendus sur les lieux pour une meilleures organisation des secours. Après le sauvetage, les recherches se sont poursuivies jusque tard dans la nuit. Les recherches qui se sont terminées au petit matin du 28 Novembre 2022 ont données un bilan officiel de 14 morts et près d'une cinquantaine de blessés. Les corps ont été acheminés grace aux ambulances de la Croix-Rouge et du SAMU vers la morgue tandis que les blessés ont été admis dans les formations sanitaires les plus proches pour la prise en charge.

results.summary: On November 27, 2022, while people were celebrating the funeral of one of their own on a playground in the Damascus district in the 3rd District of Yaoundé, a large piece of land detached and overturned on the tent that sheltered the guests. They thus found themselves trapped in both the tarpaulin and the earth. The population, attracted by the screams, began to carry out a rescue as best they could. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of local residents, several people could not be saved. Alerted, the emergency services (Gendarmerie, Police, Cameroon Red Cross and the National Fire Brigade) went to the scene for a better organization of the rescue. After the rescue, the search continued until late at night. The search, which ended in the early morning of November 28, 2022, gave an official toll of 14 dead and nearly fifty injured. The bodies were transported by Red Cross and SAMU ambulances to the morgue while the wounded were admitted to the nearest health facilities for treatment.
results.name: CMR: Landslide - 2022-11 - Landslide in the Damascus district of Yaoundé

field_reports.summary: CMR: Complex Emergency - 2022-10 - Epidemies (Monkeypox and choléra) and floods
field_reports.description:
Selon de nombreuses sources, notamment les branches locales de la Croix-Rouge Camerounaise, UNHOCHA et des structures administratives (Districts de santés, Sous-préfectures...), les pluies ont été très abondantes d'où des inondations signalées dans les Régions de l'Extrême-Nord et de l'Ouest. Bien que ces inondations aient causé d'importants dégâts, c'est surtout après les pluies que les véritables conséquences ont été ressenties. En effet, la montées des eaux a entrainé la sorties des fleuves et autres courts d'eau de leurs lits. 

Les inondations rendent plus vulnérables des populations qui vivaient déjà dans des conditions assez précaires (risque de crise alimentaire, insécurité, accès très limité aux soins de santé et à l'eau...). C'est dans ce contexte tumultueux qu'apparaissent encore les épidémies de choléra et de variole du singe. des maladies connues pour leur propagation assez rapide dans un environnement en proie à l'insalubrité. En moyenne, 8 Régions sur les 10 du Cameroun sont exposées aux risques d'une des 2 maladies. La situation s'annonce plus grave en ce moment où une grande partie du pays entre dans la saison sèche, rendant l'accès à l'eau encore plus délicat. La situation actuelle fait état de près de 50 000 personnes affectées par les inondations dans deux Départements de la Région de l'Extrême-Nord ; 23 districts avec 12952 cas notifiés dont 1157 confirmés avec 272 décès liés au choléra. Le Monkeypox quant à lui a déjà touché 8 districts de santé avec 50 cas suspects avec 12 cas confirmés et 2 décès dans 5 Régions. En outre, le pays fait également face à deux autres épidémies dont la fièvre jaune 22 cas et la rougeole 53 cas.

results.summary:
According to many sources, including the local branches of the Cameroon Red Cross, UNHOCHA and administrative structures (Health Districts, Sub-prefectures, etc.), the rains were very abundant, resulting in flooding reported in the Far North and West Regions. Although these floods caused significant damage, it was especially after the rains that the real consequences were felt. Indeed, the rising waters have led to the emergence of rivers and other streams from their beds.

Floods make populations more vulnerable who were already living in rather precarious conditions (risk of food crisis, insecurity, very limited access to health care and water, etc.). It is in this tumultuous context that cholera and monkeypox epidemics continue to appear. diseases known for their fairly rapid spread in an environment plagued by unsanitary conditions. On average, 8 out of the 10 regions of Cameroon are exposed to the risks of one of the 2 diseases. The situation is more serious at this time when a large part of the country is entering the dry season, making access to water even more difficult. The current situation shows that nearly 50,000 people are affected by the floods in two departments of the Far North Region; 23 districts with 12952 reported cases of which 1157 are confirmed with 272 cholera-related deaths. Monkeypox has already affected 8 health districts with 50 suspected cases with 12 confirmed cases and 2 deaths in 5 regions. In addition, the country is also facing two other epidemics including yellow fever with 22 cases and measles with 53 cases.
results.name: CMR: Epidemic- 2022-10 - Epidemics (Monkeypox and cholera) and floods

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
Une épidémie de cholera sévit au Cameroun depuis fin 2021. Si jusque là, les autorités sanitaires avaient pu maitriser la situation, l'on remarque une nouvelle envolée du nombre de nouveaux cas dans 5 Régions sur les 10 que compte le pays. En effet, depuis le 12 Mars 2022 on voit une relance de l'épidémie dans les différents districts de santé. Au 20 Mars le nombre de cas cumulé dans les Régions du Sud-Ouest, Littoral, Sud, Centre et Nord était de 2299 cumulés. La Région du Sud Ouest qui est la plus touchée avec plus de 1580 cas confirmés et plus 40 décès, la région se retrouve débordée.
Pour apporter une réponse à cette nouvelle flambée, le Gouvernement à travers le Ministère de la Santé Publique prévoit la mise en place des Unités de Traitement additionnelles dans tous les District de Santé de 
Tiko et Buea (Sud Ouest)
• Mise en œuvre de la stratégie CATI (former une sorte de bouclier de protection) au tour de chaque ménage touché dans les Districts affectés dans les Régions du Sud-Ouest et du Centre 
Capacitation de certains laboratoire dans les Hôpitaux régionaux dans le diagnostic de confirmation du Cholera
• Formation des personnels de santé dans les bonnes pratiques de prélèvement, de conservation et d’acheminement des échantillons 
de Choléra
• Supervision formative des acteurs impliqués dans la gestion des données des districts de santé en épidémie.
• Plaidoyer pour la mobilisation des ressources
La situation globale reste néanmoins très préoccupante au vu des cas de plus en plus nombreux et le risque de décès en communauté très élevé.
field_reports.description: Depuis le début de cette nouvelle épidémie, le système de santé dans les district de santé a été mis en alerte. Les organisations communautaires (comme les branches locales de la Croix-Rouge Camerounaise...) travaillent aux côté des formations sanitaires. Cependant au vu de la dernière relance, l'on comprend que des efforts supplémentaires et constants sont nécessaires pour pouvoir rapidement circonscrire et voire maitriser la flambée.

field_reports.description: L'on note plusieurs édifices publics effondrés, des pilonnes d'electricité endommagés; ceci entraine la restriction des mouvements  de personnes et des biens dans la localité, l'insécurité qui s'accroit par le manque éclairage, la destruction des greniers et des champs (communautaires et individuels)fait planer sur la population une menace d'insécurité alimentaire. La zone a connue également de nombreuses incursions des groupes armés.L'imminence de la rentrée scolaire met une pression supplémentaire sur les populations sinistrées qui ont trouvé refuge dans les écoles.
